text:
The default apache index page is installed in the current location: /var/www/apache2-default/index.html On my system the content of this file is:

It works!

Also, this file has no trailing newline which is malformed. The default apache site should be informative with pointers to documentation, not a childish one line statement such as this. It looks highly unprofessional. I appreciate why the original page was removed - because too many people were contacting Apache about sites which had nothing to do with them, but there has to be an alternative to this. Even a 404 message would be better than this. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/apache2/+bug/89364
creator: nslater@gmail.com
slive@apache.org
text:
I don't agree with "unprofessional". I certainly agree it is "uninformative",
but the site administrator can get the information they need from other
locations in the distribution. And anyone seeing this page who is not a site
administrator will not be helped by any amount of information we put there.

I'm curious about the "malformed" bit. Is there a spec saying that there needs
to be a trailing newline on html files? In any case, I don't see how it is
negatively affecting anybody.

As far as the content, we have tried every reasonable alternative for the
content of this page, including having text written by professional tech
writers. We still get more confused (and often abusive) messages than we care to
deal with. If you have suggestions, I'd be pleased to hear them.

I don't believe that omitting the page entirely is an improvement, since that
gives even less information to admins, gets hidden by MSIE's "friendly" error
messages, and doesn't provide an example of a page that can be easily replaced
with real content.

Finally, since this was originally a Ubuntu bug, I should point out that Ubuntu
is free to put whatever they want in the default index.html. Many third-party
distributors replace that page with their own info. But we'd request that any
contact information point towards the distributor, and not apache.

creator: nslater@gmail.com
text:
How about:

Your website has not been configured yet.

Contact the site administrator who will tell you how to start adding content to your website.

As for the newline issue - this is required by POSIX standards. Google for "end with newline" for examples...

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
I can imagine three types of people who may be reading this message:

1. Person installing apache.
2. Person responsible for a website after its installation.
3. Random web surfer stumbling on unconfigured server.

Your text helps only number 2, and the amount of help it really provides is
minimal (approaching zero). Minimal may be better than nothing. Except that I
believe this text will hurt person number 3. They will be more confused by this
message than they would be by the simple "it worked" (which can't confuse very
much because it is completely undecipherable for number 3). Some of the more
clueless ones will start yelling in every direction that they never asked for
any d*mn website.

(Another problem with putting some text there just to look more "professional"
is that we will soon have people wanting to translate it to their native
language. We wound up spending way too much time dealing with translations of
the old page, especially considering this is something that, in an ideal world,
will only be seen once.)

Believe it or not, a lot of thought has gone into this over the years.

Finally, on the newline issue, it appears to me that newlines are required for
several specific file formats (including plain text) but not for html. But I
guess we could consider them a "best practice". I'll go add one to trunk.

creator: basant.kukreja@sun.com
text:
Adding new line character will certainly help some developers like me. When I
use curl to get the index.html (using curl --dump-header - -o - http://host/),
I get the "Shell Prompt" in the same line (after it works). It was annoying so
I keep adding new line in my index.html.

Thanks for considering it to add a new line character in default index.html.
